children.content: Reason is the best way to write React
Reason's react bindings are the best way to write React.
Grab bag of things I want to say
And we're hiring! So come talk to me if that sounds fun.
I'm also one of the hosts of the ReasonTown podcast, which you should check out if you want to learn more about Reason & its community.
Hi! I'm Jared, and I do mobile & web development at Khan Academy, where we're building a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.
My goal with this talk is that by the end, you'll be able to answer these three questions.
"Type systems will make you a better JavaScript developer"
Now, one of the premises of this talk is that "type-safe react" is something that's desirable -- how many of you are already on board with that?
"Type systems will make you a better JavaScript developer"
It also works if your coworkers need some convincing :)
For those of you who aren't, I recommend this talk that I gave at ReactConf last year -- I do a deep dive into why type systems will help you in your life.
!a Reason is a new syntax & toolchain for OCaml
Reason is a new syntax & toolchain for OCaml.

Now, you might have heard of OCaml from those lists of "5 languages you should learn to make you a better programmer" -- OCaml's been around for 20 years, and has had a ton of work put into it, but its community has remained quite small.

Reason is an attempt to do what Elixir did for Erlang -- invest really heavily in the newcomer experience, make really slick developer tools, use a syntax that will be more accessible to folks coming from mainstream backgrounds, and generally grow the community.
To get this started I'm going to need to give y'all a little bit of background.
So the goals of reason are to *both* easy to get started & welcoming to newcomers, **and** provide you the powerful tools you need to maintain a codebase in the long term.
But, if you were paying attention to David Kopal's lightning talk yesterday, you already know this :)
As it turns out, when Jordan Walke was inventing React, he didn't start out with JavaScript -- he prototyped in StandardML, which is a cousin of OCaml.
As a result, some of the core concepts of React don't feel completely at home in JavaScript.

Immutability, for example -- we have it by convention, in react. You're not supposed to mutate state directly, you should call setState with a new version of the object. -- if you do mutate your state, or mutate objects you send down as props, weird things might happen.
Also with types -- React shipped with propTypes as a way to have some better guarantees about the contract between components, but they aren't nearly as helpful as a full type system.
Now, on that second point, you might be thinking "I've got types already!"
This might seem a little funny, given that React is a JavaScript library -- how could you have a binding in another language be the best way to use a library?
Reason is the best way to write React
this is a natural question -- especially because Facebook is behind both flow and Reason. -- why are they investing in both?
I'm going to first answer this with pictures.
Why should I use Reason, and not Flow or TypeScript?
Why Reason and not Flow or TypeScript?
And javascript is totally where the party's at.
ok, apparently I have to have a story about this pie
but, we're not seeing the whole picture here -- (advance)
So here we have two boats -- javascript, and ocaml
Now, I don't want to give the wrong impression -- this javascript boat isn't going to sink, necessarily. You could always add in a pump!
If we look beneath the surface --- at **the most important part of the boat**, we see some major differences.
Altough, there are a ton of holes in those boat, so maybe let's bring a couple more pumps on board.
and, these pumps really slow down the ship, because they're heavy, and they take a lot of effort and energy to keep running.
But, at this point --- you can't really play ping pong because the pumps are in the way
I see the difference here, as where they're coming from.
Flow & TypeScript, are both starting with with JavaScript, and trying to make it more like a well-typed language -- adding some safety & maintainability.

Reason, is starting with OCaml -- a well-typed language with lots of safety & power, and trying to make it more like JavaScript -- more familiar, more accessible to newcomers, with a smoother development experience.
Here's the way I think of it...

One of the things I want to highlight here is stability --- with each release of Flow and TypeScript (which is on a monthly cadence), there are breaking changes to the type system. Things that used to be errors that no longer are, or things that are now errors that weren't before.
And it makes sense -- flow and typescript are *new* type systems, trying to accomplish the very difficult task of allowing javascript idioms while adding as much safety as they can.

But this causes a real maintenance burden if you've got a large codebase -- upgrading to the latest version of flow or typescript can cost a lot. Also, good luck if you're using a library that depends on a different version of the type system.
With Reason, we're using the type system that has been honed and developed over the past 20 years! It is very stable.
There are 100 stackoverflow questions about Reason, 5000 about OCaml
There are 2k stackoverflow questions about Flow
There are 50k stackoverflow questions about TypeScript
TypeScript and Flow don't have nearly the safety guarantees, but they're much better than plain JavaScript.
So, by all means -- please use types! They will make your life better
flow gives me an error, and I dont know why
Why Reason and not Flow or TypeScript?
And actually, Elm and Reason have a lot in common! And a lot of the choices we've made with Reason have been inspired by Elm :).
Similar to how Reason is taking OCaml and making it more accessible, Elm is starting from Haskell and making it safer, simpler, and better-tuned for web ui development.
People also frequently ask me about elm! If you're going to go to the effort of switching to a whole new language, why not go all the way & use Elm?
Focus -> very focused on being the best for making UIs on the web
One of Elm's core principles is safety --- which it goes all-in on, to the point that there is no runtime exception system!
Also, javascript interop with elm takes a fair bit of doing, because Elm wants to keep the dangers of javascript at arm's length -- you can only use message passing.
In Reason, we allow much simpler & easier javascript interop, but it doesn't have as much safety guarantees.
Here are a couple of key differences as I see them.
Elm goes all-in on safety, but can be more cumbersome as a result. Elm's community & ecosystem is much farther along than Reason's.
I would say that we're at the point where teams of up to about 10 developers could get up & running for front-end development, and the benefits would definitely outweigh the costs
Be aware of the cost of change
most things are like javascript, but with more structure
can't have objects with arbitrary junk in them. same with arrays etc.
can have named arguments, optional arguments, and default values!
most things are expressions -- so the last expression in a function body is the return value. And "if" block is an expression, same as
the basic idea is to have it look as much like javascript as is reasonable

```
let x = 10; /* int */
let y = Some(20.); /* option(float) */
let z: string = "hello"; /* string */
let names = ["me", "you", "them"]; /* list(string) */
```
I should mention that OCaml has very good type inference -- I write very few type annotations when using reason.
not sure how far to dive into that side of things
Hmmm I want to motivate more, like showing places where the javascript would be dangerous
Ok, let's dig into the React side of things
maybe also toss in a bit of styles
let's look at a basic component. It just accepts props, it's stateless, so we don't need to define any state type or anything
here we're introduced to the reducer!! All state transitions are well-defined, easy to track down.
The organization of redux, with the portability & composability of local state.
A button that, when clicked, increments a counter.
The organization of redux, with the portability & composability of local state

Well, to prepare you for this, let's take a look at currying real quick.
Ok have y'all had occasion to do this? You've got a component and all you're doing is prefilling some props, then passing in all the other props.

"In the talk I gave last year at ReactConf, I talked about how Types make you a better javascript developer.
First I'll go through what it looks like adding in some reason to an existing js codebase.
{2} Adding it to your existing project

```
$ $1npm i --save-dev bs-platform$
$ cat > bsconfig.json
$2{
  "name": "myapp",
  "refmt": 3,
  "sources": ["src"],
  "package-specs": [
    {"module": "commonjs", "in-source": true}
  ]
}$
$ $3./node_modules/.bin/bsb -make-world$
# now all your .re files are compiled to .js files
```
Also, some people are working on a tool that will generate flow & typescript types from your reason code.
it would be a real shame if, by integrating reason into your typescript app, you actually *lost* some type safety because of the boundary.
generate type-safe bindings to TypeScript and Flow from Reason code

One of the things that most excites me about Reason is the potential for compiling to native. I've done some experimentation, and released a game to native ios, native android, native macos desktop, and the web.

Alright! If you want a more in-depth tutorial on getting started with Reason and React, look for "A ReasonReact tutorial". Also take a look at the ReasonTown podcast, and I have more tutorials + talks listed on my website.
Thank you!
